Question: The milk goes bad. What was the cause of this?
Choices: (A) The cells of milk have some changes. (B) Mike forgot to add rennet to the milk.

Milk is a perishable product that contains living cells, including bacteria. When milk is exposed to air, bacteria start to grow and multiply, causing the milk to spoil. The bacteria break down the lactose in the milk, producing lactic acid, which causes the milk to sour and curdle. Therefore, the most plausible cause of milk going bad is the changes in the cells of milk due to bacterial growth. Mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects the salivary glands, causing swelling and pain. However, in rare cases, mumps can lead to complications such as inflammation of the brain (encephalitis), inflammation of the testicles (orchitis), and inflammation of the ovaries (oophoritis). One of the less common complications of mumps is ischemia, which occurs when there is a lack of blood flow to a particular part of the body. Ischemia can lead to tissue damage and even organ failure if left untreated. Therefore, it is more plausible that the patient was diagnosed with ischemia as a result of the mumps infection.
